comments.commentBody: My sainted father collected bordeaux and burgundies in the 60s.  He died in 1985.  My son is now making pinot noir in Oregon.  We opened a '61 Chambolle-Musigny-Charmes that my dad bought for $6.  It was a delicious pinot with wonderful acidity, still wonderful and definitely in large part enjoyed as a fitting toast to the dear departed and as a nod to the next generation.

Amazing. I've dipped my toes into the construction waters (one in NYT, hopefully more someday), and this puzzle feels nothing short of wizardry to me.  I once tried to get 1-across and the last across clue to have matching clues in a puzzle I was making, just for a cute semi-related bonus-effect to the theme... couldn't do it without ruining those corners.  That was ONE clue I was trying to match!  In a 15x15, not a darn Sunday, for goodness sake!  This is wizardry. Nothing short of it, Mr. Niederman.  Incredibly well done, thank you.  I also really love the thought that every single of solver had to first fill in a down clue unless they were guessing, because, by definition, every single across answer could be more than one thing!

and Elke
Martin- can you get oysters any FRESHAIR than that ?
Enjoy.
Wow, that silly "screen grab" sure added a lot to this article.  Why even put that stupid picture up there?

The young white man on the left in the photo is Arthur Henderson Smith. His book Chinese Characteristics is free on Google Books. He lived in China 53 years. Chinese are basically the same now as then.

Montreal, I agree with you. You are spot on.

What we need is conserve and produce less, enough for a comfortable life. A 1,200 or sq.ft. space for up to 3 people, with 1&1/2 baths, enough heating in winter and some cooling in summer, mostly with attic fan with minimal use of AC. A TV & wifi connection and 1 or 2 computers and cell-phones. If well-connected mass transit is made available a car is unnecessary. With bicycles we can get by.

We need good libraries to expand our knowledge. Private art collections are too much of a luxury. We should have access to art galleries & museums. More social gatherings and leisure time activities, which are hardly expensive, ought to be encouraged.

Produce a lot less & consume a lot less. Per capita waste should be minimal-to-negligible. Simple living ought to become fashionable.

All-in-all, Bernie Sanders's democratic socialism is a good model. But his policies are US-centric, against NFTA & TPP. Both would lead to, I THINK a lot less misery to tens of millions of poor people.

However, I am not for increase in trade volume. Strictly speaking, trade should be minimal. As far as possible a country or region should produce most it needs locally & import only things they can't produce locally, in the long run.

You will kinda find the same town in pretty much all international coverage.
Some countries such as UK or France with permanent correspondents fare a bit better but only slightly.

While green technology might help to alleviate man-made pollution a bit, the key word is still "Man-Made" - overpopulation burdened the earth and stretch nature's ability to heal itself from abuse. China had been exemplary in controlling population explosion with the one-child policy. They must stay on the program. Too bad other countries did nothing significant to curb population growth. Recently Canada's newly elected government brings more middle-east refugees into Canada after much calculation and politically correctness. A TV team revisited a typical refugee family one year after their arrival. The couple brought with them four young kids. Neither parents could find job yet, they can't speak English. are employed yet. The wife is now pregnant with the fifth kid. Unfortunately some culture will not do anything to help bring population growth down due to religious or traditional values. It is worrisome problem for the whole world.

Being a good steward of antibiotics is a mantra in healthcare these days and one I believe in. I have however bemusedly reflected as I counsel a patient that no they do not need a antibiotic for their viral illness, we are beset around us by massive amounts of antibiotics from overuse in other counties as well as our industrial food system, as is noted in this story.

Here in the Pacific Northwest as well we have a influx of Chinese. I love the multicultural aspect of living in a community such as that, though I recognize there is other sides. Several in converstaions reflect a direct reason for leaving and or having a home here is the relative clean air and environment.
We now spend billions on bottled water, fresh air anyone? Just pay at the counter.

China already imports cans of "clean" air from locations in Australia and other countries with low pollution levels.  Has done for years.  Probably more factual than bottled water, which often comes from an urban tap (aka faucet).

Our Aussie Air is 100% certified Dinky Di, Ridgy Dink, Bonza , Ya Beauty, No Worries Bottled Up there Cazaly Fair Dinkum Oz Air!*

Available with the following Aromas :

1. Vegemite
2. Kangaroo
3. Dagwood Dog
4. Chiko Roll
5.Raw Prawn
6. Port Kembla

More Aromas To Come!

I just came back from China.  They have to use bottled water since it's so polluted.  Everyone carries bottled water.  The pollution was pretty scary, and we were surprised the people admit it and talk about it openly.
Not to worry.  Chinese bureaucrats, like Republicans, like to breathe clean air.

Nice thought but, Trump's appointments to related sectors of government do not project that dream but a demise of regulation and continuation of governing for the CEO's. He may for show prevent some off-shoring but the jobs are not coming back.
This is horrible....but they're not going to stop making our iPhones, right?

Foxconn is moving to Vietnam where labor is cheaper as Chinese wages go up.
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/23/business/international/china-jobs-dona...
Make you feel better?
Pretty sure he's just being sarcastic, referring to the fact that people in the US don't care about the welfare in China as long as we get our iPhones.

This is a lot like Winston Churchill's initial reluctance to admit the smog crisis of 1952 that killed 12,000 people was a result of coal-fired plants.  Although, it took a few meteorological events keeping pollution trapped in London for things to get catastrophic.

Manufacturing output in this country has increased considerably over the last 20 years as manufacturing jobs have decreased. Automation is, of course, the reason. This is one of the major issues of our time, as the trend of depending on automation (meaning robotics) will continue in exponential fashion, unabated.

This is the conversation we need to be having in this country, not how to bring back all those jobs. I suspect Trump knows this, meaning he scammed at lot of people during the race. Even Carrier's CEO has stated that to remain competitive, a lot of the "saved" jobs will eventually be lost to automation.

It doesn't look like those people who have lost those jobs will even be able to get jobs in the fast food industry for much longer if the new Secretary of Labor has his way. I don't begin to have the answers to this very serious issue, but it does seem that greatly improving access to good education without the prospect of drowning in student debt has to be part of the solution.

Taiwan is an independent country. It is not part of China historically or culturally.

The guo min dang army of Chiang kai shek occupied the land with the fall of its reign in China and made its Mandarin language and culture the official one of Taiwan. They murdered many thousands of Taiwanese intellectuals in an attempt to destroy their culture.

Taiwan will still be Taiwan and the Taiwanese the Taiwanese long after the communists are gone from China and China is once again returned to the Chinese.

Let Taiwan move to more IT dominance like Israel and it will be even more free of the communist shackles and dominance.

President Trump is in a position to radically alter the balance of power.

He was elected to do this and has a mandate for radical change.

More to come.

The strategy of the Taiwanese military revolves around the assumption that the United States will help Taiwan if a Chinese invasion were to occur. However, this assumption has led doubts in the 21st century. One of the few reasons why the U.S. might want to help Taiwan is through the pressures of South Korea and Japan. Taiwan stands on a strategic location in the Pacific and any expansion by China (as seen with the Senkaku Island disputes) will send alarm bell ringing in South Korea and Japan.

In essence, there is nothing we can do if the United States refuse to intervene militarily.

@JT
Many points most irrelevant . China was an ally in WWII and as such was given a seat in the UN Security Council but by 1971 the strangeness of the arrangement being held by a small island was enough for the Peoples Republic of China to be given that seat by the UN and Nixon’s visit, an avid anti-communist, in 1972 sealed the one China deal for the world, or most of it.
Taiwan, in the various forms it took as dictatorship evolving into an elective democracy, has lived with that arrangement but not gleefully.
It wishes a large role but even Tsai Ing-wen has been careful not to raise the issue of Independence. Wise diplomacy will let that issue evolve historically but America under Trump could do otherwise and the costs will not be minimal; speculation unsless.

Taiwan was a de-facto colony of US from 1950s to about 1980, with US military
bases across the island. Without US, it would be part of China long ago.

Hmm... spiraling debt, political corruption, disunity among a supposedly united population, and a leader that is not selected by popular vote of the citizens. I'm starting to have a hard time telling the difference between China and the United States. If enviromental regulations get rolled back as far as Trump promises, we might not even be able to see the difference through the smog.

@Alen Klein
China is not the Soviet Union which was a composite of many differing nations “unified” by Stalin feared dictatorship and apparatchiks climbing too high as others did without. CCP has merged in a free enterprise sector and while corruption exist it is not very different if at all from other developing nations. But centralized economic control colored by globalization and diminished sovereignty yielding to corporate elites seems the wave of the future. America is not far removed is it?
Only if we still have the freedom to talk about it critically.  I rather think Trump will try to curtain free speech next year.
I wish.
Let's hope that we get to keep our noisy and argumentative freedoms.  I would think Herr Trump would be attacking those pretty soon.
